Award.AwardTitle: LTREB RENEWAL: Predicting the Responses of Swallows and Their Insect Prey to Climate Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies the effects of weather variation on breeding Tree Swallows and their flying insect prey. It combines field and laboratory research with new and sophisticated technology to pursue four main objectives. The first is to understand the biological basis for observed variation in egg laying date. Second, the researchers will refine and deploy a new sensor-node network to test the effects of altered nest temperatures on parental care and the development of chicks. Third, new collaborations will be initiated to document individual swallow flight and foraging in relation to changing weather conditions. Finally, detailed studies of local variation in insect emergence and sensitivity to weather will link changes in food availability with changes in bird dynamics. These objectives will complete the final five years of a ten-year research plan to reach a comprehensive understanding of how individual birds and bird populations respond to climate variation.

This research helps explore how changes in the severity and variation of global climates are affecting the breeding biology of birds, and the long-term data are fueling a collaboration in eastern Canada and the northern US searching for the causes of population declines in aerial insectivores, including tree swallows. This study continues to provide training for an international team of students of all levels, and it serves as idea-generator for large-scale comparative studies through the pan-American Golondrinas de las Americas network. Results are communicated to the broadest possible audience through the many outlets of the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, and the preceding projects, have produced a body of work that has broadly investigated the life history of a small short-lived passerine bird. Concentrating on lay date, a trait that has been responsive to climate, the work has shown how this single trait interacts with other life history traits and how it can act as an indicator of many other aspects of individual quality. The work’s long-term database has been instrumental in a better understanding of how phenotypic phenological adjustments can bear unanticipated longer-term fitness risks. The research has shown how environmental changes during chick development can have profound and lasting effects on organismal function and fitness, and it has served to emphasize how food quality can often be as important as food quantity in affecting avian reproductive performance. Though based at few sites in upstate NY, the research has shown how movement ecology can illuminate local studies and how such studies can productively be part of much larger geographic and phylogenetic studies of life history variation. The work has made it clear that the responses of both breeding birds and their aerial insect prey to climate change are as understandable, and as idiosyncratic, as any other aspects of their organismal biologies.

 


Last Modified: 02/19/2020
Modified by: David W Winkler
